articles.title: Mediterranean Diet Linked With 23% Lower Risk of Dementia - SciTechDaily
articles.description: Eating a traditional Mediterranean-type diet – rich in foods such as seafood, fruit, and nuts – may help reduce the risk of dementia by almost a quarter, a new study has revealed. Experts at Newcastle University found that individuals who ate a Mediterranean-…
articles.content: According to a study by Newcastle University, consuming a traditional Mediterranean diet consisting of foods such as seafood, fruit, and nuts may decrease the risk of developing dementia by up to 23%… [+4797 chars]

articles.title: Anyone want an International Space Station? Slightly used - The Register
articles.description: NASA expects to spend about $1 billion to bring it down safely
articles.content:
NASA expects to spend around $1 billion to deorbit the International Space Station as the orbiting laboratory reaches its end of service in the 2030s.

articles.author: Mansur Shaheen
articles.title: Mediterranean diet rich in nuts, oils and leafy veg slashes risk of an early death in women - Daily Mail
articles.description: An Australian research team found that eating a Mediterranean diet could drop a woman's risk of dying by any cause by 23 percent. Heart disease and stroke risk dropped in particular.
articles.content:
Following the Mediterranean diet can slash a woman's chance of an early death by nearly a quarter, a study suggests.
In the study of more than 700,000 women, the famed diet decreases a woman's chanc… [+2995 chars]
